description: A savory, nutritious, and staple Ugandan dish that combines the intense umami flavor of dried silver fish with the soft, earthy texture of cowpeas, creating a protein-packed stew.
origin_region: Nationwide, especially Central and Eastern Uganda

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: This is a classic, humble dish found in many Ugandan homes. It is affordable, highly nutritious, and provides a strong flavor that complements bland starches like posho and matoke perfectly.

ingredients.name: Dried Silver Fish (Mukene)
ingredients.notes: Rinsed thoroughly to remove debris and excess salt

ingredients.name: Fresh or Dried Cowpeas
ingredients.notes: If using dried, soak overnight. Fresh cowpeas are shelled from their pods.

ingredients.name: Salt
ingredients.notes: Use sparingly, as the silver fish is often salty

steps.instruction: If using dried cowpeas, boil them in a separate pot in plenty of water for 45-60 minutes until tender. Drain and set aside. If using fresh cowpeas, they will cook with the stew.
Place the silver fish (mukene) in a bowl and rinse thoroughly under cold running water to remove sand, small stones, and excess salt. Drain well.
In a large saucepan, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the chopped onions and sauté until soft and translucent, about 5 minutes.
Add the minced garlic and optional curry powder. Sauté for another minute until fragrant.
Add the chopped tomatoes and cook for 5-7 minutes, mashing them with the spoon until they form a thick paste and the oil begins to separate.
Add the rinsed silver fish to the pot. Stir well to coat with the tomato and onion mixture, and cook for 3-4 minutes to allow the fish to toast slightly and release its flavor.
Add the pre-boiled (or fresh) cowpeas to the pot. Pour in the water and add salt cautiously (taste first). Stir everything to combine.
Bring the stew to a boil, then reduce the heat to low, cover the pot, and let it simmer for 20-25 minutes. If using fresh cowpeas, simmer for 30-40 minutes or until they are tender.

cooking_indicators.visual: stew thickens and cowpeas are soft
cooking_indicators.texture: cowpeas are tender but not mushy, sauce is thick

steps.instruction: Once the cowpeas are tender and the stew has reached your desired consistency, remove from heat. Adjust seasoning if necessary.
Serve hot alongside a staple food like Posho (Ugali), Matoke, or Rice.

serving_suggestions: Best served hot with Posho (Ugali), Matoke (steamed green bananas), or Rice. A side of steamed Sukuma Wiki (collard greens) complements it well.
